Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying the physical presence test instead of a qualitative residency test
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 200 days due to caring for her ill mother and business trips
Court_Ruling: Citizenship Judge's decision was reasonable and within discretion
Defendant_Behavior: Absences from Canada exceeding allowable limits under physical presence test
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian reasons for absence: family care and business obligations
Legal_Standard: 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence vs. qualitative residency assessment
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judgeâ€™s decision to Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Documentation of absences for caregiving and business travel
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and reasons for absences from Canada
Relief_Sought: Grant of citizenship or remittal for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: Applicants must meet minimum physical presence or demonstrate qualifying residency
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient justification to override strict physical presence requirement
Cause_Description: Applicant failed to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement due to extended absences for family care
Evidence_Handling: Absence records and personal circumstances considered but not sufficient to excuse non-compliance
Evidence_Assessment: Judge assessed nature and purpose of absences but applied strict physical presence test
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judges have discretion to apply physical presence test; decision falls within reasonable range
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, Federal Court on appeal
